name: Agua Canyon Connecting Trail Trailhead at Ponderosa Canyon
description: This strenuous connector trail descends from the forested cliffs of Ponderosa Point to join the Under the Rim Trail, dropping approximately 1,000 feet into the canyon.

images.title: Agua Canyon Connecting Trail
images.altText: A sign reading Agua Canyon Connecting Trail leads up stairs to a forested cliff
images.caption: The Agua Canyon Connecting Trail leads down from Ponderosa Point

raw_listing_description: Trail Closed due to Rockslide This trail descends 1.6 miles (4.0 km) to its junction with the Under the Rim Trail approximately 1,000 feet (305 m) below.
raw_body_text: Agua Canyon Connecting Trail Difficulty: Strenuous Total Distance: 1.6 miles (2.6 km) Ascent/Descent: 428 feet (130 m) / 1,201 feet (366 m) Average time: 1-2 hours Trail Closed due to Rockslide This trail may be inaccessible during mid-winter due to snow depths ranging from 2-15 ft (0.7-5 m). This trail descends 1.6 miles (4.0 km) to its junction with the Under-the-Rim Trail.

name: Bristlecone Loop Trailhead
description: This high-elevation loop winds through ancient bristlecone pines and forests of fir and pine, offering expansive views of colorful orange and white cliffs.

images.title: Bristlecone Loop Trail Midway Point
images.altText: A brightly colored cliff of orange and white rock with a forested cliff above
images.caption: The trail provides views of colorful cliffs, near and distant, as well as bristlecone pines

raw_listing_description: A short path through fir and pine leads to the easy 1.0 mi/1.6 km Bristlecone Loop, as well as the 8.8 mile (14.2 km) backcountry Riggs Spring Loop and 23 mile (37 km) Under-the-Rim Trail. Though the Bristlecone Loop trail only climbs 200 feet (61 m) and is rated as Easy, be sure to carry water, wear ankle-supporting footwear, and postpone your hike if lightning is expected.The Bristlecone Loop reaches elevations over 9,100 feet (2778 m).
raw_body_text: Bristlecone Loop Trail Difficulty: Easy Total Distance: 1.0 miles (1.6 km) Elevation change: 200 feet (61 m) Average time: 1-2 hours This trail may be inaccessible during mid-winter due to snow depths ranging from 2-15 ft (0.7-5 m). The Bristlecone Loop reaches elevations over 9,100 feet (2778 m).

name: Bristlecone Loop Trailhead at Rainbow Point
description: This easy loop hike winds through fir and pine forests at high elevation, offering views of ancient bristlecone pines and vibrant red and white rock cliffs.

images.title: Bristlecone Loop Trail
images.altText: Cliff of vibrant red and white rock and distant cliffs below forested plateau rim
images.caption: The trail provides views of colorful cliffs, near and distant, as well as bristlecone pines

raw_listing_description: A short path through fir and pine leads to the easy 1.0 mi/1.6 km Bristlecone Loop, as well as the 8.8 mile (14.2 km) backcountry Riggs Spring Loop and 23 mi/37 km Under-the-Rim Trail.
raw_body_text: Bristlecone Loop Trail Difficulty: Easy Total Distance: 1.0 miles (1.6 km) Elevation change: 200 feet (61 m) Average time: 1-2 hours This trail may be inaccessible during mid-winter due to snow depths ranging from 2-15 ft (0.7-5 m). The Bristlecone Loop reaches elevations over 9,100 feet (2778 m).

name: Bryce Canyon Shared Use Path
description: A scenic paved multi-use path connecting the hoodoos of Red Canyon to the park's interior at Inspiration Point, winding through the Dixie National Forest and across the Paunsaugunt Plateau.

images.title: Shared-use Cyclists
images.altText: Two cyclists ride along paved forested path
images.caption: Both pedal-assist e-Bikes (motor of less than 750 W) and traditional bikes are welcome on the path

raw_listing_description: This path provides passage from Bryce Canyon city through Dixie National Forest into Bryce Canyon National Park. Hike, bike, walk or wheel all 5 miles to Inspiration Point, or stop at the shuttle stops and other amenities along the way.
raw_body_text: See the Park at Your Speed The Shared-Use Path provides a scenic opportunity for pedestrians, leashed pets, cyclists, roller or in-line skaters, longboards, non-motorized scooters, wheelchairs, and cross-country skiers to access the park and surrounding areas. This 18 mile (29 km) path connects the hoodoos of Red Canyon on the western edge of the Paunsaugunt Plateau with Inspiration Point within the park and it generally follows SR-12 and UT-6.

name: Fairyland Loop Trailhead
description: The Fairyland Loop circles around Boat Mesa and offers an immersive journey through a landscape of vibrant red rock spires and unique geological features.

images.title: Fairyland Loop Boat Mesa
images.altText: A red rock landscape of rock spires and forest with a beaten path travelling through it
images.caption: The Fairyland Loop circles around the feature known as Boat Mesa

raw_listing_description: The Rim Trail This is the northern end of the 5.5 mile (8.9 km) Rim Trail that begins in the south at Bryce Point. Fairyland Loop The Fairyland Loop is a strenuous 8 mile (12.9 km) loop.
raw_body_text: Fairyland Loop Trail Difficulty: Strenuous Total Distance: 8.0 miles (12.9 km) Elevation change: 1,716 feet (523 m) Average time: 4-5 hours Along the the Peekaboo Loop, the Fairyland Loop provides some of the best strenuous hiking in the park. It can be begun from either the Tower Bridge Trailhead or further notice at Fairyland Point (not accessible by vehicle in winter months).

name: Mossy Cave Trail
description: This trail follows a creek to the sheltered overhang of Mossy Cave and the scenic Water Canyon, featuring a waterfall in the summer and icicles in the winter.

images.title: Mossy Cave Trail
images.altText: A creek meanders through red rocks with red rock formations in the background.
images.caption: See a waterfall in the summer and icicles in the winter on one of the park's easier hikes.

name: Navajo Loop Trailhead
description: This iconic loop descends through narrow limestone walls and switchbacks, offering views of towering Douglas-fir trees and the park's most famous hoodoo, Thor's Hammer.

images.title: Two Bridges side of Navajo Loop
images.altText: Switchbacks descend along a redrock trail between tall walls of rock and trees
images.caption: The Two Bridges side of the Navajo Loop descends into the Bryce Amphitheater

raw_listing_description: The iconic Navajo Loop Trail begins and ends at Sunset Point, travelling by switchbacks down between narrow walls of colorful limestone with views of towering Douglas-fir trees and the park's most famous hoodoo: Thor's hammer. The loop has two sides, the Two Bridges side and the Wall Street side.
raw_body_text: Navajo Loop Difficulty: Moderate Total Distance: 1.3 miles (2.2 km) Elevation change: 550 feet (168 m) Average time: 1-2 hours The iconic Navajo Loop Trail begins and ends at Sunset Point, travelling by switchbacks down between narrow walls of colorful limestone with views of towering Douglas-fir trees and the park's most famous hoodoo: Thor's hammer. The loop has two sides, the Two Bridges side and the Wall Street side.

name: Peekaboo Loop, Hat Shop, and Under-the-Rim Trail Trailhead
description: This trail descends over 1,000 feet into the Bryce Amphitheater, leading hikers through dense hoodoo formations and diverse forests beneath colorful rock spires.

images.title: Hat Shop Hoodoos
images.altText: A forested depression surrounded by bright orange and pink limestone cliffs and rock spires
images.caption: HIkers heading down the Under-the-Rim Trail will find the Hat Shop hoodoos two miles down trail

raw_listing_description: Here the Peekaboo Loop, Hat Shop, and Under the Rim Trails all descend from the Bryce Point area.
raw_body_text: Peekaboo Loop Trail Difficulty: Strenuous Total Distance: 5.5 miles (8.8 km) Elevation change: 1,555 feet (473 m) Average time: 3-4 hours The Peekaboo Loop trail quickly descends over 1,000 feet (305 m) to the floor of the Bryce Amphitheater before travelling north into one of the densest areas of hoodoo formation in the park. Here shaded north-facing slopes retain precipitation and support a diverse forest among these colorful spires of rock.

name: Queens Garden Trailhead
description: This trail descends into the Bryce Amphitheater along a scenic ridgeline to reach a unique hoodoo resembling Queen Victoria amidst a landscape of colorful rock spires.

images.title: Queen's Garden Trail
images.altText: A glowing landscape of red and orange rock spires and forest
images.caption: The Queen's Garden descends a long ridgeline past fins and hoodoos within the Bryce Amphitheater

raw_listing_description: One of the park's most popular trails, the Queen's Garden trail descends and bends 0.9 miles (1.4 km) along a ridgeline down to a unique hoodoo said to resemble Queen Victoria. Of the six trails that descend into the Bryce Amphitheater, the Queen's Garden Trail is considered the least strenuous; though due to the park's high elevation and steep grades in some areas, it is still categorized as a moderately strenuous hike.
raw_body_text: Queen's Garden Trail Difficulty: Moderate Total Distance: 1.8 miles (3.0 km) Elevation change: 320 feet (98 m) Average time: 1-2 hours One of the park's most popular trails, the Queen's Garden trail descends and bends 0.9 miles (1.4 km) along a ridgeline down to a unique hoodoo said to resemble Queen Victoria (be sure to travel down the spur trail at the bottom of the trail to see this hoodoo). The varied and colorful rock formations that surround this hoodoo, are described as many sculptures and other ornaments within the Queen's "Garden".

name: Riggs Spring Loop Trailhead at Yovimpa
description: This backcountry loop descends from the rim through solitary forests and across raised promontories, providing sweeping views of distant pink cliffs.

images.title: Riggs Spring Loop Trail
images.altText: Distant orange rock cliffs are seen through a forest along a sandy trail
images.caption: The Riggs Spring Loop Trail provides views of the cliffs and forest below Yovimpa Point

raw_listing_description: Experience the solitude of Bryce's forested backcountry on the Riggs Spring Loop. Descending from the rim, this 8.8 mile (14.2 km) trail meanders through forests and raised promontories, offering stunning views of pink-hued cliffs in the distance.
raw_body_text: Riggs Spring Loop Difficulty: Strenuous Total Distance: 8.8 miles (14.2 km) Ascent: 2,503 feet (763 m) Average time: 4-6 Hours This trail may be inaccessible during mid-winter due to snow depths ranging from 2-15 ft (0.7-5 m). Descending from the rim, this 8.8 mile (14.2 km) trail meanders through forests and raised promontories, offering stunning views of pink-hued cliffs in the distance.

name: Rim Trail Bryce Point Trailhead
description: The Rim Trail follows the edge of the Bryce Amphitheater, connecting all major viewpoints and offering spectacular vistas of the park's iconic red rock badlands and spires.

images.title: Rim Trail
images.altText: Two hikers pause along a path to view a red rock landscape of badlands and spires at a cliff's edge
images.caption: The Rim Trail provides easy to moderate walks along the edge of the Bryce Amphitheater.

raw_listing_description: This is the southern end of the 5.5 mile (8.9 km) Rim Trail that begins in the south at Bryce Point and ends in the north at Fairyland Point.
raw_body_text: The Rim Trail Difficulty: Varies (Easy to Moderate) Total Distance: 5.5 miles (8.9 km) Ascent/Descent (South to North): 1,330 feet (405 m) / 1,825 feet (556 m) Average time: 3-4 hours The 5.5 mile (8.9 km) Rim Trail begins in the south at Bryce Point and ends in the north at Fairyland Point. The trail connects all viewpoints in the Bryce Amphitheater area and can be accessed at each of them.

name: Rim Trail Inspiration Point Trailhead
description: The Rim Trail offers a scenic walk along the edge of the Bryce Amphitheater, connecting iconic viewpoints and providing expansive views of red rock badlands and spires.

images.title: Rim Trail
images.altText: Two hikers pause along a path to view a red rock landscape of badlands and spires at a cliff's edge
images.caption: The Rim Trail provides easy to moderate walks along the edge of the Bryce Amphitheater.

raw_listing_description: The 5.5 mile (8.9 km) Rim Trail begins in the south at Bryce Point and ends in the north at Fairyland Point. The trail connects all viewpoints in the Bryce Amphitheater area and can be accessed at each of them.
raw_body_text: The Rim Trail Difficulty: Varies (Easy to Moderate) Total Distance: 5.5 miles (8.9 km) Ascent/Descent (South to North): 1,330 feet (405 m) / 1,825 feet (556 m) Average time: 3-4 hours The 5.5 mile (8.9 km) Rim Trail begins in the south at Bryce Point and ends in the north at Fairyland Point. The trail connects all viewpoints in the Bryce Amphitheater area and can be accessed at each of them.

name: Rim Trail Sunrise Point Trailhead
description: The Rim Trail offers panoramic views of the Bryce Amphitheater's iconic hoodoos and red rock badlands as it follows the cliff's edge between Bryce Point and Fairyland Point.

images.title: Rim Trail
images.altText: Two hikers pause along a path to view a red rock landscape of badlands and spires at a cliff's edge
images.caption: The Rim Trail provides easy to moderate walks along the edge of the Bryce Amphitheater.

raw_listing_description: The 5.5 mile (8.9 km) Rim Trail begins in the south at Bryce Point and ends in the north at Fairyland Point. The trail connects all viewpoints in the Bryce Amphitheater area and can be accessed at each of them.
raw_body_text: The Rim Trail Difficulty: Varies (Easy to Moderate) Total Distance: 5.5 miles (8.9 km) Ascent/Descent (South to North): 1,330 feet (405 m) / 1,825 feet (556 m) Average time: 3-4 hours The 5.5 mile (8.9 km) Rim Trail begins in the south at Bryce Point and ends in the north at Fairyland Point. The trail connects all viewpoints in the Bryce Amphitheater area and can be accessed at each of them.

name: Rim Trail Sunset Point Trailhead
description: This scenic path follows the edge of the Bryce Amphitheater, connecting major viewpoints and offering panoramic vistas of iconic red rock badlands and spires.

images.title: Rim Trail
images.altText: Two hikers pause along a path to view a red rock landscape of badlands and spires at a cliff's edge
images.caption: The Rim Trail provides easy to moderate walks along the edge of the Bryce Amphitheater.

raw_listing_description: The 5.5 mile (8.9 km) Rim Trail begins in the south at Bryce Point and ends in the north at Fairyland Point. The trail connects all viewpoints in the Bryce Amphitheater area and can be accessed at each of them.
raw_body_text: The Rim Trail Difficulty: Varies (Easy to Moderate) Total Distance: 5.5 miles (8.9 km) Ascent/Descent (South to North): 1,330 feet (405 m) / 1,825 feet (556 m) Average time: 3-4 hours The 5.5 mile (8.9 km) Rim Trail begins in the south at Bryce Point and ends in the north at Fairyland Point. The trail connects all viewpoints in the Bryce Amphitheater area and can be accessed at each of them.

name: Swamp Canyon Loop Trailhead
description: The Swamp Canyon Loop descends from the rim to the canyon floor, offering hikers views of crumbling pink cliffs and a journey into the park's scenic backcountry via the Under-the-Rim Trail.

images.title: Swamp Canyon Loop
images.altText: Grey sand and low shrubs with tall pink cliffs crumbling into forest below
images.caption: The Swamp Canyon Loop descends to the Under-the-Rim Trail and a sense of park backcountry

raw_listing_description: The moderately strenuous 4.0 mi/6.4 km Sheep Creek/Swamp Canyon Loop begins here. The trail descends 647 ft/198 m to the canyon floor on a 3 - 4 hour hike.
raw_body_text: Swamp Canyon Loop Difficulty: Moderate Total Distance: 4.0 miles (6.4 km) Ascent/Descent: 1,026 feet (313 m) / 1,034 feet (315 m) Average time: 3-4 hours The moderately strenuous 4.0 mi/6.4 km Swamp Canyon Loop begins here. The trail descends 647 ft/198 m to the canyon floor on a 3 - 4 hour hike.

name: Tower Bridge and Fairyland Loop Trailheads
description: This trail descends along Boat Mesa through bristlecone pine groves to provide views of unique rock formations like Tower Bridge and the Sinking Ship.

images.title: Tower Bridge Trail Bristlecones
images.altText: A winding white sediment path winds past pine trees and a landscape of redrock cliffs and spires.
images.caption: The Tower Bridge Trail descends along Boat Mesa and passes by groves of bristlecone pines.

raw_listing_description: Similar in difficulty to the Queen's / Navajo Combination loop, but far less travelled, the Tower Bridge trail provides excellent views of Boat Mesa, Sinking Ship, and other distant features within and outside the Bryce Amphitheater area of the park.
raw_body_text: Tower Bridge Trail Difficulty: Moderate Total Distance: 3.0 miles (4.8 km) Elevation change: 802 feet (245 m) Average time: 2-3 hours Similar in difficulty to the Queen's / Navajo Combination loop, but far less travelled, the Tower Bridge trail provides excellent views of Boat Mesa, Sinking Ship, and other distant features within and outside the Bryce Amphitheater area of the park. The trail begins 0.25 miles (0.4 km) north of Sunrise Point along the Rim Trail and is part of the larger 8 mile (12.9 km) Fairyland Loop.

name: Tropic Trail Trailhead
description: This unique point of entry into the Bryce Amphitheater climbs steadily from a lower elevation forest of juniper and pine toward the park's iconic orange limestone spires.

images.title: Tropic Trail
images.altText: Tree branches partially obscure distant orange limestone spires
images.caption: The Tropic Trail leads through a juniper and pine forest toward the heart of the Bryce Amphitheater.

raw_listing_description: One of the least-travelled front-country trails in the park, the Tropic Trail provides a unique point of entry into the Bryce Amphitheater area of the park. While all other hikes in this area begin on the rim and descend into the amphitheater, the Tropic Trail begins in lower elevation forest and steadily climbs to its intersection with the Peekaboo Loop, Navajo Loop, and Queen's Garden Trails.
raw_body_text: Tropic Trail Difficulty: Moderate Total Distance: 1.7 miles (2.7 km) Elevation change: 591 feet (180 m) Average time: 1-2 hours One of the least-travelled front-country trails in the park, the Tropic Trail provides a unique point of entry into the Bryce Amphitheater area of the park. While all other hikes in this area begin on the rim and descend into the amphitheater, the Tropic Trail begins in lower elevation forest and steadily climbs to its intersection with the Peekaboo Loop, Navajo Loop, and Queen's Garden Trails.

name: Under-the-Rim and Riggs' Spring Trailhead
description: This strenuous backcountry trail offers hikers solitude as it traverses Bryce Canyon's forested landscapes and follows a red rock path beneath towering cliffs.

images.title: Hikers along Under-the-Rim Trail
images.altText: Two backpackers hike along red rock path with distant forest and cliffs
images.caption: The Under-the-Rim Trail descends from Rainbow Point toward distant Bryce Point

raw_listing_description: The Under-the-Rim Trail is approximately 22.9 miles (36.9 km) from Bryce Point to Rainbow Point. Connecting trails offer access from the park's Scenic Drive and intersect the Under-the-Rim Trail at Swamp Canyon, and Whiteman Bench.
raw_body_text: Under-the-Rim Trail Difficulty: Strenuous Total Distance: 22.9 miles (37 km) Ascent: 5,884 feet (1,793 m) Average time: 2-3 Days This trail may be inaccessible during mid-winter due to snow depths ranging from 2-15 ft (0.7-5 m). Experience the solitude of Bryce's forested backcountry on the Under-the-Rim Trail.

name: Whiteman Connecting Trail Trailhead
description: A forested trail that descends from the rim to the Under-the-Rim Trail, offering scenic views of the Paria Valley and distant pink-hued cliffs.

images.title: Whiteman Connecting Trail
images.altText: A forested slope foreground with red rock cliffs and plateaus beyond
images.caption: The Whiteman Connecting Trail provides distant views of the Paria Valley along its descent

raw_listing_description: Experience the solitude of Bryce's forested backcountry on the Under the Rim Trail. Descending from the rim, this 22.9 mile (37 km) trail meanders through forests and meadows, offering stunning views of pink-hued cliffs in the distance.
raw_body_text: Whiteman Connecting Trail Difficulty: Moderate Total Distance: 1.0 miles (1.6 km) Ascent/Descent: 16 feet (4.9 m) / 490 feet (149 m) Average time: 1-2 hours This trail may be inaccessible during mid-winter due to snow depths ranging from 2-15 ft (0.7-5 m). This trail descends 1.0 mile (1.6 km) to its junction with the Under-the-Rim Trail.

name: Figure-8 Combination
description: This ultimate hike combines the Queen's Garden, Navajo Loop, and Peekaboo Loop, taking hikers deep into the amphitheater to witness iconic red rock hoodoos and formations.

images.title: Hoodoos along Peekaboo Connector
images.altText: Red rock formations on top of a steep sandy slope with distant red rock formations in the background
images.caption: Views along the connector trail between the Queen's/Navajo trails and the Peekaboo Loop.

name: Queen's/Navajo Combination Loop
description: This popular loop combines the open views and unique hoodoos of the Queen's Garden Trail with the iconic switchbacks and towering canyon walls of the Navajo Loop.

images.title: Hikers on Queen's Garden
images.altText: Hikers walk along a trail towards an open archway in the red rock
images.caption: Hikers approach an archway on the Queen's Garden side of the Combination Loop

name: Riggs Spring Loop
description: This backcountry loop winds through diverse spruce, fir, and bristlecone pine forests while providing sweeping views of distant cliffs.

images.title: Riggs Spring Loop Trail
images.altText: Forested hills with rock formations in the background
images.caption: Views from the Riggs Spring Loop

name: Sunset Point to Sunrise Point Hike
description: Meander along the rim of the iconic Bryce Canyon Amphitheater on a paved path that offers stunning views of the red rock hoodoos below.

images.title: Sunset Point at Sunrise
images.altText: Looking down from above over a scenery of irregular red rocks with the sun rising behind them
images.caption: A view from Sunset Point at sunrise

name: The Rim Trail
description: Following the edge of the Bryce Amphitheater, this trail connects major viewpoints and offers continuous, spectacular vistas of the park's iconic hoodoos and red rock badlands.

images.title: HIkers along the Rim Trail
images.altText: Two hikers pause along a path to view a red rock landscape of badlands and spires at a cliff's edge
images.caption: The Rim Trail provides views along the edge of the Bryce Amphitheater and connects viewpoints.

name: Tower Bridge
description: This hike follows the southern portion of the Fairyland Loop trail, descending to a short spur that leads hikers to the unique Tower Bridge hoodoo formation.

images.title: Tower Bridge in snow
images.altText: A pale red rock formation covered in snow surrounded by green trees
images.caption: The Tower Bridge hoodoo is at the end of a 1/4-mile spur trail.

name: Peekaboo Loop
description: This scenic loop descends from Bryce Point into a canyon filled with towering red rock hoodoos. Hikers will experience an immersive journey through unique geological formations while sharing the path with seasonal horse and mule tours.

images.title: Peekaboo Loop
images.altText: An overhead view of red rock formations with a blue sky in the background
images.caption: Views from the Peekaboo Loop trail

name: Hat Shop
description: Descending from Bryce Point, this trail leads hikers into the backcountry to see a cluster of unique balanced-rock hoodoos with expansive views of the Grand Staircase.

images.title: Hat Shop Overlook
images.altText: A landscape of red rocks in the foreground with hazy mountains on the horizon
images.caption: Views along the Hat Shop trail.

name: Navajo/Peekaboo Combination Loop
description: This scenic figure-eight loop descends from Sunset Point to combine the Navajo and Peekaboo trails, offering close-up views of iconic red rock formations like Thor's Hammer.

images.title: Thor's Hammer from Navajo Loop
images.altText: A view over a landscape filled with red rock formations with the iconic thor's hammer formation.
images.caption: The Thor's Hammer hoodoo can be seen from Sunset Point and the Navajo Loop portion of this trail.

name: Under-the-Rim Trail
description: A backcountry trail that traverses scenic forests and meadows, offering hikers solitude and expansive views of distant cliffs.

images.title: Hikers on the Under the Rim Trail
images.altText: Two people walk a trail of red earth wearing gear on their backs.
images.caption: Hikers carry their gear while enjoying a hike on the Under-the-Rim trail.

name: Walk the Rim Trail
description: This scenic path follows the edge of the Bryce Amphitheater, connecting several major viewpoints and offering spectacular vistas of the park's iconic red rock badlands and spires.

images.title: HIkers along the Rim Trail
images.altText: Two hikers pause along a path to view a red rock landscape of badlands and spires at a cliff's edge
images.caption: The Rim Trail provides views all along the edge of the Bryce Amphitheater and connects viewpoints
